sentence.text: The patient, a girl, was the first child of healthy non-consanguineous parents.
The pregnancy was unremarkable and the prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks gestation was normal.
Following delivery, the patient was noted to have deficient skull ossification, bowed limbs, and omphalocele.
The omphalocele was small (3·3 cm), contained intestine only, and was closed by primary repair with no subsequent complications.
The head circumference was 35 cm (ca. 50th percentile) but there were widely patent cranial sutures, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a depressed nasal bridge.
On examination of the extremities in the neonatal period, the patient was noted to have bowing of the right lower limb with an associated anterior skin dimple and leg length discrepancy.

The diagnosis of hypophosphatasia was suspected because of the impaired mineralisation and the radiographic finding of a Bowdler spur of the right fibula (Fig. 1), generally considered pathognomonic of hypophosphatasia [2, 6,16].
Investigations included a karyotype which was normal (46,XX) and a skeletal survey which demonstrated deficient skull ossification and lack of ossification of both clavicles and pubic rami.

Alkaline phosphatase activity at 3 days of age was 22 U/l (reference range for age: 155–555 U/l) and all the subsequent measurements of alkaline phosphatase activity have been below the normal range for age including the most recent value at 9 years of age which was 101 U/l (reference range for age: 185– 425 U/l).
Urinary phosphoethanolamine was elevated at 46 mmol/ mol creatinine (normal: <10 mmol/mol creatinine) and plasma-5’- pyridoxal phosphate was elevated at 269 nmol/l (normal: <110 nmol/l).
These values are consistent with the diagnosis of childhood hypophosphatasia.
The patient was re-evaluated at 11.2 years of age.
Her psychomotor development was normal.
Her general health had been good but there were two episodes of grand mal seizures secondary to minor trauma as her skull remained largely unossified (Fig. 2).
Her height was 115 cm (<2nd percentile) and the leg length discrepancy persisted.
On examination, her skull had a bilobed appearance due to the cranial vault defect and she had marked hypertelorism and upslanting palpebral fissures.
At age 8 years, three supernumerary molars which were submerged and ectopically positioned had been surgically removed.
Most of her secondary teeth were unerupted and those visible were primary dentition.
She was noted have exaggerated lumbar lordosis and mild scoliosis (Fig. 3a).
Review of radiographs revealed findings of classic CCD including multiple pseudoepiphyses of the metacarpals, hypoplasia of the clavicles, and hypoplastic pubic rami.
The bones were quite osteopenic in appearance (Fig. 3a, b).
